title: Woman who killed three children after hitting them in her truck is convicted of reckless homicide
text:
Alyssa Shepherd (pictured) was convicted of reckless homicide, criminal recklessness and a misdemeanor count of causing injury by passing a school bus with the safety arm extended

An Indiana woman who slammed into four children with her pickup truck - killing three and critically injuring the other – as they were crossing the street to their school bus was convicted of three counts of reckless homicide.

A Fulton County jury also found 24-year-old Alyssa Shepherd guilty of a felony count of criminal recklessness and a misdemeanor count of causing injury by passing a school bus with the safety arm extended.

She fatally struck 6-year-old twins Xzavier and Mason Ingle, their sister 9-year-old Alivia Stahl and critically injured 11-year-old Maverik Lowe.

When Shepherd took the stand on Friday at the Fulton County Courthouse, her family members and the victim’s families listened to her recount the horrifying moments leading up to three siblings’ untimely death.

‘The only way I can describe it is an out-of-body experience,’ she said according reporters inside the courtroom.

‘I was a mess.’

Shepherd fatally struck 6-year-old twins Xzavier and Mason Ingle (left and right) and their sister 9-year-old Alivia Stahl (middle) on October 30, 2018

11-year-old Maverik Lowe (pictured) was critically injured in the accident, suffering broken ribs and a busted knee cap among other wounds

When Shepherd’s attorney asked her to recall the moment she ran into four school children, she described her emotions ranging from disbelief to hysterical.

According to Shepherd, she initially didn’t recognize the school bus placed across the street from the victims' mobile homes in Rochester or the warning sign extended from the bus’s side.

During her probable cause hearing, authorities say Shepherd claimed to she didn’t connect the pieces until it was too late to stop her vehicle.

‘She did not recognize it immediately as a school bus. In fact, she said she was trying to figure out what it was,’ Indiana State Police Detective Michelle Jumper said.

‘She knows she dimmed her lights for it because it had headlights, but she couldn’t make out what it was.’

‘By the time she realized what it was, the kids were right there in front of her.’

Shepherd (pictured) leaving the Fulton County courthouse after initial court appearance in November of 2018

Fulton County Prosecutor Michael Marris said in his closing arguments that the bus stop had been there for 50 years and never had a fatality before Shepherd’s accident.

He also reminded jury that the driver behind Shepherd saw the warning sign and was able to tell there was a school bus ahead.

‘The thing that makes me sick here,’ Marrs said, ‘is that this never should have happened.’

Shepherd could face up to 21 and a half years in prison, depending on her decided sentence.

Her sentencing is scheduled for December 18.

Brittany Ingle, the mother of the three siblings (pictured), said: 'I don't think we'll ever feel closure, but this will go toward healing'

Neither Shepherd nor her attorneys had any comments while leaving the courtroom.

However, the parents of the children told reporters after the trial that they had no sympathy for Shepherd’s verdict.

Brittany Ingle, mother of the three siblings, implied the damage had already been done.

She said: ‘I don't think we'll ever feel closure, but this will go toward healing.’

On October 30, 2018, Shepherd was driving her Toyota Tacoma with three children in the backseat prior to the crash.

She had just dropped her husband, Neil Shepherd, off to work at 7.05am and was driving her younger brother to her mother’s house.

She rounded onto Ind. 25, a road she frequented often but rarely at that time of day.

Pictured: a map showing the location of the children's homes, the waiting school bus and Shepherd's car at the time of the accident

According to her attorney, Shepherd couldn’t make out the vehicle ahead of her and confused a freightliner driving behind the bus as one large vehicle.

‘The circumstances of the bus, with the freightliner behind it, combined to create the profile of one vehicle, making it seem like it's a semi that's moving. And she's confused about what she sees,’ he said.

Up the road, the four school children were preparing to cross the two-lane highway to get to their morning school bus.

Xzavier, Mason, Alivia and Maverik were walking out of their housing complex around the same time as Shepherd was driving down the street.

The school bus was waiting on the side of the road with the warning sign blinking, signalling cars to stop in both directions to let children pass.

Pictured: Emergency services at the scene of the accident after the four children were struck by Shepherd

Unfortunately, Shepherd reportedly never saw that sign.

A witness said she watched the horrific scene unfold, hoping Shepherd would slow down from her 45mph cruise.

The ‘distraught’ bus driver, who also witnessed the incident, reportedly blasted his horn to get Shepherd’s attention seconds before impact.

Afterwards, Shepherd reportedly stopped her vehicle and asked a nearby witness what happened.

She said: ‘What did I hit?’

‘You just ran over kids. You probably killed them all,’ the man answered.

Ultimately, the four victims were struck by Shepherd’s vehicle to dire results.

Lowe, who was thrown 30 feet from the collision and was hospitalized, was left in critical condition.

The young boy was forced to undergo several surgeries, according to a GoFundMe page created to cover medical expenses.

Lowe suffered broken ribs, a busted knee cap, fractures in his arms and wrist, and his legs were held being held together by rods.

He also had slipped disks in his spine by his neck.

After the accident, the local school district supervisor announced the bus stop would be moved from across the street and into the mobile park home of the victims.
description: Alyssa Shepherd, 24, was convicted on three counts of reckless homicide after running her pickup truck into four school children walking to the school bus - killing three siblings and critically injuring another
